English.lblDemonstrationAnsPolLong: Civilians were forced to attend Communist party festivities that promoted comunist ideologies and praising Nicolae Ceausescu. Consequences for not attending could include being fired from your job or harsh torture.

English.lblChildhoodQ: What was it like to be a child during this period?
English.lblFoodAnsPolLong: Food was scarce and there was no variety in stores. Basic necessities were rationed and of much worse quality compared to today.
English.lblSchoolAnsPolLong: School was very strict. The party wanted to demonstrate how educated and proper its citizens were - kids were even required to write in ink in a calligraphy style. All classrooms had a portrait of Ceausescu and students had to chant slogans about the Romanian Communist Party and how great Ceausescu is every day. There were lessons about the communist ideology and students were punished for not being able to recite Ceausescu's policies and speeches.
English.lblSchoolQ: How was learning in school different in this time?

English.lblWarsawAnsPolLong: The Warsaw Pact was a military alliance formed in 1955 by the Soviet Union and several Eastern European countries in response to the formation of North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) in 1949. English.lblWhatWasRevolutionAnsPolLong: The Revolution of 1989 was a major turning point in Romanian history. It began with protests in Timișoara
English.lblWhatWasRevolutionAns: The Revolution of 1989 brought an end to decades of dictatorship and marked the beginning of Romania’s transition to democracy.
English.lblNicolaeAnsPolLong: Nicolae Ceaușescu was the leader of communist Romania from 1965 until 1989. At first
English.lblNicolaeAns: Leader of communist Romania from 1965 until 1989 who is remembered as one of Europe’s most repressive and controlling dictators.

English.lblElenaAns: Wife of Nicolae Ceaușescu and one of the most powerful people in the country
English.lblGheorgheAnsPolLong: Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej was a senior member of the Communist Party but was displeased with Pauker's loose understanding of Stalinism and would become the prime minister of Romania in 1952. During his time he tightened his grip on Romania due to his strict following of Marxism. He sought to distance Romania from the USSR after a high ranking Soviet Officer denounced the crimes Stalin had committed. Gheorghiu-Dej was General Secretary of Romania's Communist Party from 1952 until his death in 1965.
English.lblGheorgheAns: General Secretary of Romania's Communist Party from 1952 until his death in 1965.
